Operator Precendence
= 1

> 2
< 2
>= 2
<= 2

& 3
- 3
* 4
(backslash) 4
/ 4
^ 4

Each individual element in the result will contain the split sequence terminator if it is found to be delimited by it. For example if you split [1,2,3,4] by a sequence of [2,3] this method will return a list with 2 byte arrays, one containing [1,2,3] and the second one containing 4. Use the Trim extension methods to remove terminator sequences.

member.name: T:Unosquare.Swan.Formatters.Json
member.summary:
A very simple, light-weight JSON library written by Mario to teach Geo how things are done
This is an useful helper for small tasks but it doesn't represent a full-featured serializer such as the beloved Json.NET

member.name: M:Unosquare.Swan.Terminal.ReadKey(System.Boolean,System.Boolean)
member.summary: Reads a key from the Terminal. This is the closest equivalent to Console.ReadKey
member.param: if set to true the pressed key will not be rendered to the output.
if set to true the output will continue to be shown. This is useful for services and daemons that are running as console applications and wait for a key to exit the program.
member.returns: The console key information

member.name: E:Unosquare.Swan.Terminal.OnLogMessageReceived
member.summary: Occurs asynchronously, whenever a logging message is received by the terminal. Only called when Terminal writes data via Info, Error, Trace, Warn, Fatal, Debug methods, regardless of whether or not the console is present. Subscribe to this event to pass data on to your own logger.

member.name: E:Unosquare.Swan.Terminal.OnLogMessageDisplaying
member.summary: Occurs synchronously (so handle quickly), whenever a logging message is about to be enqueued to the console output. Setting the CancelOutput to true in the event arguments prevents the logging message to be written out to the console. Message filtering only works with logging methods such as Trace, Debug, Info, Warn, Fatal, Error and Dump Standard Write methods do not get filtering capabilities.
